document.docTitle: Three New Carnivorous sponge species (Demospongiae: Cladorhizidae) from the Seamounts of the Central Indian Ridge

emphasis.docTitle: Three New Carnivorous sponge species ( Demospongiae : Cladorhizidae ) from the Seamounts of the Central Indian Ridge

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: National Centre for Polar and Ocean Research ( NCPOR ), Ministry of Earth Sciences (MoES), Headland Sada, Vasco-da-Gama, Goa, India —403804

subSection.paragraph:
Deep-sea sponges are an imperative component of benthos. They accumulate the suspended organic matter by filtering large quantities of water and, with their intricate structures, provide the most suitable habitats for various associated organisms. We describe three new cadorhizid sponges from the Central Indian Ridge (CIR), Indian Ocean. The sponges are part of the benthic sledge collection conducted onboard the MGS Sagar in the CIR region. A detailed taxonomic description of two novel species,
Asbestopluma ( Asbestopluma ) indiyansis
sp. nov .
, and
Asbestopluma ( A. ) bharatiyae
sp. nov .
are provided based on the morphological and molecular (mtCOI and 28S) markers. In addition, another new carnivorous species
Chondrocladia sagari
sp. nov .
is described based on the morphological and mtCOI marker. The systematic and descriptions of new species are discussed based on the structural and phylogenetic analysis. Our study shows that the cladorhizid fauna of the seamounts from the CIR are unique and represent regionally endemic benthic habitats.

Key words: Porifera, deep-sea, Carnivorous sponge, Cladorhizidae , new species ,
Asbestopluma
,
Chondrocladia , DNA
barcodes, Central Indian Ridge, Indian Ocean

The family Cladorhizidae is exceptional within the phylum Porifera. The family comprises an exciting group of deep-sea sponges with well-developed carnivory and (their) ability to entangle, capture passively, and envelop small groups of crustaceans. They are known for their unique carnivorous feeding strategy, an evolutionary adaptation to oligotrophic conditions in deep-sea water ( Vacelet & Boury-Esnault 1995 ), their diversity, and evolution ( Vacelet & Custódio 2007 ,
Hestetun et al . 2015
, 2016). Previously described cladorhizid species from the southwest Indian Ocean were based on the “ Challenger ” and second “
Galathea
” expeditions ( Ridley & Dendy 1886 , 1887 , Lévi 1964 ; Topsent (1909) and Koltun (1964) . The lack of systematic deep-sea biological surveys in the Central Indian Ridge (CIR) prompted detailed exploration in the seamount areas (
Rogers et al . 2010
, Rogers & Taylor 2012 ). The detailed studies of biodiversity, ecological role, and various functions of carnivorous species, from seamounts of the South West Indian Ridge (SWIR), were carried out by Rogers & Taylor (2012) ,
O’Loughlin et al . (2013)
,
Laptikhovsky et al . (2017)
, and
Djurhuus et al . (2017)
. A recent study by
Hestetun et al . (2017a)
suggested that benthic species in the upper bathyal of the southwest Indian Ocean Ridge ( SWIOR ) were unique and characterized by regionally endemic cladorhizid species.
Hestetun et al . (2017a)
described nine new cladorhizid species in the SWIOR seamounts based on RRS James Cook cruise JC066. Similarly, seventeen new species of carnivorous sponges were described from bathyal to abyssal depths off Eastern Australia during the RV
Investigator
2017 Abyss Expedition ( Ekins, Erpenbeck & Hooper 2020 ) from an expedition extending from the Coral Sea to the seamounts south of Tasmania (
O’Hara et al . 2020
).

An excellent systematic review of the family Cladorhizidae and closely related genera and their associated microscleres has been produced by
Hestetun et al . (2016)
. The species of the family Cladorhizidae are similar in morphological characters with biogeographical affinities and molecular studies support their biogeographical distribution along the SWIOR , southwest Pacific Ocean, and the southwest Atlantic Ocean. The CIR’s active hydrothermal vent fauna composition had links to both Atlantic Ocean and Pacific Ocean vent assemblage (
Van Dover et al . 2001
,
Hashimoto et al . 2001
,
Bachraty et al . 2009
,
Zhou et al . 2018
,
Surya Prakash et al . 2022
). The detailed benthic study of the active Edmond field showed the communities’ existence of an inactive megabenthic assemblage at the southern CIR (
Gerdes et al . 2019
), supporting higher habitat heterogeneity and rich diversity (
Cuvelier et al . 2014
).
Desbruyeres et al . (2006)
and
Bachraty et al . (2009)
reported the dependency of endemic species on the chemoautotrophic bacteria groups for food availability in the deep-sea ecosystems. However, there is a lack of information on the species diversity and distribution of carnivorous sponges in the CIR region. The previous study in CIR did not report any cladorhizid sponges, mainly because of poor sampling, and most of the cladorhzids are very small in size. Cladorhizid sponges have been a focus of many recent studies, yet species in the Indian Ocean and the neighboring regions remain unexplored. Therefore, in the present study, we describe three new species of Cladorhizid sponges from the Central Indian Mid-Oceanic Ridge, sampled near the active Edmond vent region and about 1.8 km away from the sampling sites at the northern CIR.

All the sponge specimens are part of the benthic sledge collection conducted onboard the MGS Sagar in the CIR (cruise no: MGS35/36, March-May 2020; Figure 1 & Table 1 ). The ultra-slowly spreading CIR extends southwestwards, beginning from the Central Indian Ridge system linking to the Mid-Atlantic Ridge system. This divergent plate boundary demarcates the African plates and Antarctic plates. It is separated at its southwest end through the Bouvet Triple Junction and at its North East end through the Rodrigues Triple Junction. All the megafauna, including sponges, were sorted, photographed, and stored in 70% ethanol until further laboratory analysis. The spicule preparations were carried out following the method of Boury-Esnault & Rützler (1997) . Spicule dimensions were measured and represented as a minimum–(mean)–maximum of lengths x widths of each spicule category under the stereo zoom light microscope (Leica DMC6200). Spicule preparations were made by dissolving the tissue in 15% sodium hypochlorite to remove the soft tissue, rinsed twice with neutralized double-distilled water, followed by rinsing with ethanol (70%) and ethanol (99%) for removal of water, and then air-dried. Finally, the spicules were gold sputter-coated for a Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) to improve the resolution (model no: SEM—JEOL JSM, Country—6360LV between the voltage range of 15–20 kV). All types of material are deposited in the National Center for Polar and Ocean Research ( NCPOR ) collection, Goa, India .

subSection.paragraph:
A small piece of the sponge tissue was used for DNA extraction by the CTAB (Cetyltrimethylammoniumbromide) method (
Sambrook et al . 1989
), which is suitable for complex material (
Erpenbeck et al . 2016
). The Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) amplification of the partial 28S rRNA gene using primers, 28S-C2-F, and 28S-D2- R , and partial mtCOI gene segment were performed (
Chombard et al . 1998
,
Folmer et al . 1994
,
Rot et al . 2006
). In brief, 25-μl reaction solution consisting of 2.5 µL of 10x PCR buffer, 2.5 µL of 25 mM MgCl2, 1 µL of 10 mM dNTPs, 1 µL of each primer (10 µM), 17.2 µL of water, 0.3 µL of DNA polymerase, and 1 µL DNA template were used. The initial denaturation temperature was 94° C for 5 minutes, followed by 34 cycles consisting of 40 seconds of denaturation (temperature 94° C), 40 seconds annealing (60°C for the 28S gene and 49°C for mtCOI), followed by 1 minute elongation at 72° C, and final elongation at 72° C for 5 minutes. Further, the PCR products were purified using ExoSap IT, and the purified PCR products were sequenced on an ABI 3500 automated sequencer (Thermofisher,) method using the BigDye-Terminator Mix v3.1. DNA sequences thus obtained were trimmed and assembled using CodonCode Aligner v 3.7.1 (www.codoncode.com). The sequence data obtained were further submitted in the NCBI GenBank database. The phylogenetic reconstructions were obtained for all
Asbestopluma
and
Chondrocladia
sequence data of the mtCOI and 28S genes. To confirm the taxonomic identity of the carnivorous sponges, aligned mtCOI and 28S genes datasets were closely compared to other carnivore sponge species retrieved from the NCBI GenBank database. MAFFT v7.313 was used for multiple sequence alignment ( Katoh & Standley 2013 ). Maximum likelihood (ML) reconstructions were performed using RAxML 8.0.26 ( Stamatakis 2014 ) under the GTRGAMMA model and 100 rapid bootstrap replicates. The reconstruction of phylogenetic trees was visualized in FigTree v1.4.4 ( Rambaut 2009 ).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Paratype .
NCPOR /HYD-CIR/0032 collection details same as holotype
,
NCPOR /HYD-CIR/0033 collection details same as holotype
.

Etymology. This species name “
indiyansis
” refers to the country ( India ). Gender is feminine.

Distribution. Species
A. ( A. ) indiyansis
sp. nov .
is presently known only from the type locality (seamounts of the Central Indian Ridge).

Shape and size. The elongated holotype ( NCPOR /HYD-CIR/0031) is attached to the dead coral. Holotype forms an unbranched, slender spicular axis arranged at right angles around the main stem. It consists of several bundles of longitudinal mycalostyles forming the main axis among rows of finner filaments tightly placed in all directions with a disc-shaped basal attachment ( Figure 2A ). The main stem of the sponge is protected by subtylostyle projecting at right angles. It measures 10.2–11.4 cm in total length, with the sponge body 2.8–3.1 mm in diameter. Colour in life is beige, whitish beige when preserved in ethanol. Paratype NCPOR /HYD-CIR/0032 has an unbranched, slender spicular axis and it has a total length of 54.3 mm , a diameter of 3.1 mm . The colour in life is beige. Paratype NCPOR /HYD-CIR/0033 is very similar to the holotype , 62.6 mm in length, with a diameter of 2.3 mm . The colour is life beige scuro when preserved ( Figure 2A–B ).
Mycalostyle. Spicules of the main axis at the core of the stem, abruptly pointed, size 1089–(1240)–1389 µm long and 32.6–(36.5)–40.4 µm wide ( Figure 3A , Table 2 ).
Subtylostyles. Spicules of lateral filaments or body, straight, fusiform, size 258.8–(288.8)–315.4 µm long and 7.7–(9)–10.1 µm wide ( Figure 3B ).
Desmas. Monocrepid, 551–(588)–808 × 25–(47.1)–75 ( Figure 3C ).

Anisochelae I. Numerous, somewhat curved shaft, 70% of the total length covering the primary tooth, alae, three dorsal processes of anisochelae within the lower end, and 30% of the full size covering two well-developed frontal teeth. The upper tooth in the central part of the spicule and lateral alae reach down almost touching the lower end. The foot of the anisochelae is developed into two diverging alae, while the central part has three teeth. The size is 42.9–47.1–51.1 µm long ( Figure 3D–E ).

Anisochelae II. Nearly spherical, the head consisting large lateral alae close to the shaft down their whole length, with a shaft strongly curved bearing two large triangular lateral fimbriae, and smaller third fimbriae in the middle. 90% of the total length is covered with a central tooth and the lower end of the anisochelae has three dorsal processes, with 10% of the full size covered by two well-developed frontal teeth. Further, the main part’s upper tooth and lateral alae reach down to touch and fit between the lower alae. The foot of the anisochelae is developed into two small diverging alae. The size ranges 29.5–40.6 µm long ( Figure 3F–H ).

Anisochelae III. Curved shaft, with 70% of its total length covered by a central tooth, lateral alae, pointed bottom teeth, and claw-like alae at the lower end of anisochelae, with two rudimentary dorsal alae. The leaf-shaped plate of the central part has upwardly-pointed central alae about 1/6th of its total length, size 13.55–(18.34)–23.12 µm long ( Figure 3H–J ).
Sigmancistras. 90° contorted, internal margin compacted, size 20.2–(22.6)–25.1 µm long ( Figure 3I–K ).
Molecular data. GenBank accession number, 28S: MW810077 , mtCOI: MW868385 .

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks. This species has a single stem with filaments in rows which is common in the genus and the two types of anisochela and sigmancistras of microsclere spicules are also typical for
Asbestopluma
. The
A. ( A. ) indiyansis
sp. nov .
species that most closely matches the habit and spicule complement and spicule morphology of
A. ( A. ) pseudoisochela Hestetun, Rapp & Xavier, 2017
,
A. ( A. ) pennatula (Schmidt, 1875)
and
A. ( A. ) cf. belgicae ( Topsent, 1901 )
.
A. ( A. ) indiyansis
sp. nov .
differs from other known species by having two types of anisochelae ( Figure 3C–E ). The new species appears similar morphology to that of the distal parts of
A. ( A. ) pseudoisochela
from the SWIOR but differs in having the desmas branching forms. The new species is also similar to
A. ( A. ) cf. belgicae
from the Southern Ocean and Southeastern Atlantic ( Koltun 1964 , Topsent 1901 ). This new species is unique among the known
Asbestopluma species
by a combination of its morphology and the unique shape of its anisochelae, and they are roughly spherical.
Asbestopluma ( A. ) bitrichela Bravo & Hajdu, 2011
,
A. ( A. ) desmophora Kelly & Vacelet, 2011
,
A. ( A. ) inexpectata Lopes & Hajdu, 2014
,
A. ( A. ) indiyansis
sp. nov .
and
A . ( Helophloeina ) stylivarians (Topsent, 1929)
have an unusual desmas and all branching forms. This new species can be distinguished from these species most easily by different spicule morphology and sizes for the smaller megascleres and microsclere.

Molecular data from
A. ( A. ) indiyansis
sp. nov .
species was included in a phylogeny of closely related
Asbestopluma species.
The phylogeny of new species is closely related to
A. ( A. ) pseudoisochela
with high bootstrap support (100%),
A. ( A. ) pennatula
, and
A. ( A. ) cf. belgicae
based on mtCOI and 28S genes.
Figures 4–5 , Table 2

subSubSection.paragraph:
Paratype .
NCPOR /HYD-IOCIR/0035 same collection details as for holotype
.

Etymology. The species name “
bharatiyae
” refers to the Bharat Dynasty. In the ancient era, Emperor Bharat ( India ) gave his name to the dynasty, referred to as Mahabharat or Akhand Bharat . Gender is feminine.

Distribution.
Asbestopluma ( A. ) bharatiyae
sp. nov .
is known only from its type locality in the seamounts of the Central Indian Ridge system.

Diagnosis: The holotype is a live sponge attached to dead coral, having a dichotomously branched main stem 0.4–0.8 mm wide. The holotype is 60.5 mm long, and the axis is 0.6 mm wide. The main axis surface tissue is somewhat uneven and covered with a mass of short fine fibers ( Figure 4A ).

Shape and size : The holotype has a dichotomously branching stem of 14 mm in length and 0.8 mm in width at the base area and 0.4 mm wide in the upper area. Tightly set filaments on both sides of its bifurcating habit. The paratype consists of three smaller fragments 5–8 mm in length with similar morphology to the holotype . White colour when preserved ( Figure 4A ).
Mycalostyles: Slightly curved, fusiform, size range: 574.4–(724.2)–851.9 µm long, 16.4–(20.4)–29.78 µm wide ( Figure 5A , Table 2 ).
Subtylostyles: straight, size range: 297.8–(362.6)–553.1 µm long, 8.7–(11.6)–14.4 µm wide ( Figure 5B ).

Anisochelae I : Head of anisochelae with large lateral alae attached to the shaft along about two-thirds of their length, with a sizeable frontal ala, ovoid. The shaft is weakly curved in the first part and has two small fimbriae close to the foot. Size range: 24.5–(32.7)–36.65 µm, shaft diameter 4.3–5.4 µm ( Figure 5C–F ).

subSubSection.paragraph: Anisochelae II: Numerous, covering rare in the main stem and very abundant in the filaments, curved shaft, and upper tooth in the central part about half the total length of the anisochelae, and lateral upper alae covering about 80% of the shaft. The lower end of the anisochelae is in the form of two small plates with a central part of the anisochelae, size range: 4.5–(5.1)–6.4 µm ( Figure 5G–H ).
Sigmancistras: Contorted, concave side flattened, size range: 19.84–(22.9)–27.7 µm ( Figure 5I–J ).
Molecular data. GenBank accession number, 28S: MW810078 , mtCOI: MW868386 .

Remarks. In terms of spicule measurements of
A. ( A. ) bharatiyae
sp. nov .
is closely related to
A. ( A. ) jamescooki Hestetun, Rapp & Xavier, 2017
, described earlier from seamounts in the Southwest Indian Ocean Ridge (
Hestetun et al . 2017a
), and
A. ( A. ) desmophora Kelly & Vacelet, 2011
which was initially described from seamounts along the Macquarie Ridge in the vicinity of New Zealand , and subsequently recorded from seamounts in the eastern Solomon Islands ( Vacelet & Kelly 2014 ).
Asbestopluma ( A. ) bharatiyae
sp. nov .
differs from
A. ( A. ) desmophora
in lacking desmas, and acanthosubtylostrongyles (which appear to be unique in the latter species compared to other members of the genus), and in the shape of the two types of anisochelae. The larger anisochelae in
A. ( A. ) desmophora
and
A. ( A. ) jamescooki
are triangular and their upper ends are palmate, while in
A. ( A. ) bharatiyae
sp. nov .
upper end of the anisochelae is more rounded, with major notches between alae and the shaft of the anisochelae ( Figure 5G–H ). The smaller palmate anisochelae are more rounded and with the alae covering the shaft in
A. ( A. ) jamescooki
than in
A. ( A. ) desmophora
. The same general spicule morphology in
A. ( A. ) jamescooki
from the SWIOR, from which
A. ( A. ) bharatiyae
sp. nov .
species from the CIR can be distinguished by geographical distance, general habitus, and other spicule measurements ( Table 2 ).
A. ( A. ) bharatiyae
sp. nov .
species has bifurcating habit similar to
A. ( A. ) furcata Lundbeck, 1905
,
A. ( A. ) jamescooki
, and
A. ( A. ) ruetzleri Hestetun, Tompkins-Macdonald & Rapp, 2017
species, but these species differ from the others by the different shapes of anisochelae.

Molecular data based on mtCOI and 28S genes from this species has been included in a phylogenetic tree which shows a separate branch of
A. ( A. ) bharatiyae
sp. nov .
and sister group to
A. ( A. ) jamescooki
with high bootstrap support (87) than in
A. ( A. ) desmophora
.
Figure 6–7 , Table 3

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. Species name “sagari” refers to the Ocean. Sagar means ‘Ocean’ in Hindi. Gender is feminine.

Diagnosis: Holotype ( Figure 6A ) an erect columnar pedunculate sponge with a slender body bearing small filaments processes. The specimen is 3.1 cm in length a 0.5 cm wide. The sponge surface is rough and rigid, and roots are missing. The colour of the sponge is white, cream to clear brown in alcohol.

Microscleres: Multidentate unguiferate isochelae is common in the body and very abundant in the swellings, with four alae at each end. Alae are relatively short, sharp, with a well-marked hull on the underside. Shaft curved, with narrow fimbriae. Size: 37–(44)–53 µm in length with a diameter of 3–(4)–5 µm ( Figure 7C ).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks. Our specimen sampled from the Central Indian Ocean, from the lower bathyal at 2103 m depth, is more similar to
Chondrocladia clavata Ridley & Dendy (1887)
species which is commonly recorded from the Southern Hemisphere (
Dressler-Allame et al . 2017
,
Ekins et al . 2020
).
C. clavata
and
C. gracilis Lévi, 1964
have similar mycalostyles in the stem as
C. sagari
sp. nov .
, but also have a tridentate unguiferate isochelae in the filaments and body, whereas
C. sagari
sp.nov .
has two categories of styles and a unique multidentate (4 alae) unguiferate isochelae and “C”&“S” shapes sigmas.
C. gracilis Lévi, 1964
has a similar spicule type (mycalostyles and subtylostyles) in the stem, body, and filaments, but these are generally smaller than those of the
C. sagari
sp. nov .
The new species is similar to previous descriptions of
C. clavata Ridley & Dendy (1887)
, and more recently
Dressler-Allame et al . (2017)
who described from the Southern Ocean, and also described at bathyal and abyssal depths off the east coast of Australia during the RV
Investigator
2017 Abyss Expedition (
Ekins et al . 2020
). Both species also resemble
C. crinita
in external morphology but have much smaller isochelae. The other species of
Chondrocladia
originally described from the Indian Ocean, namely
C. clavata Ridley & Dendy, 1886
,
C. gracilis Lévi, 1964
,
C. multichela Lévi, 1964
, and
C. dichotoma Lévi, 1964
, having differed in spicule characters. The morphological descriptions of the new species have been compared with all other species of
Chondrocladia
in Table 4 .

The
Chondrocladia sagari
sp. nov .
is recovered as a sister species to
C. vaceleti Cristobo, Urgorri & Rios, 2005
with high bootstrap support (48%) and shows a separate branch in the phylogenetic tree based on the mtCOI gene ( Figure 8 ).
Molecular data. GenBank accession number mtCOI: MW868387 .

Distribution.
Chondrocladia sagari
sp. nov .
is known for its type locality in the seamounts of the Central Indian Ridge system.

subSection.paragraph:
In the present study, we described two new species under the subgenus
Asbestopluma
and one species under the genus
Chondrocladia
. All the specimens were successfully sequenced for phylogenetic analysis. The results obtained from the phylogenetic analysis are given in Figure 8 (mtCOI) and Figure 9 (28S). We used the DNA sequence of all recognized taxa providing a mtCOI and 28S dataset representing the complete set of known and unknown species of carnivorous (family Cladorhizidae ) sponges. The phylogenetic analysis shows the clear molecular separation, with new sequences clustering with closely related species
Asbestopluma ( A. ) indiyansis
sp. nov .
,
A. ( A. ) bharatiyae
sp. nov. ,
and
Chondrocladia species
(
Chondrocladia sagari
sp. nov .
). Our results using the maximum likelihood method, support the new species position with a high bootstrap value of 98% and monophyly of species. Further, the phylogenetic analysis shows the evolutionary relationship of the genera
Asbestopluma
and
Chondrocladia
, which are comparable to those species described by
Hestetun et al . (2016
, 2017a , 2017b ),
Dressler-Allame et al . (2017)
,
Ekins et al . (2020)
. Of the three CIR new species:
A. ( A. ) indiyansis
sp. nov .
is a sister species to
A. ( A. ) pseudoisochela Hestetun, Rapp & Xavier, 2017
from the SWIOR with high bootstrap support (100%),
A. ( A. ) cf. belgicae ( Topsent, 1901 )
from the Southern Ocean and
A. ( A. ) pennatula (Schmidt, 1875)
from the North-East Atlantic. Whereas,
A. ( A. ) bharatiyae
sp. nov .
is a sister species to
A. ( A. ) jamescooki
described by Hestetun et al . 2017 from the SWIOR and
A. ( A. ) desmophora Kelly & Vaceleet, 2011
from the southwest Pacific with high support based on mtCOI and 28S genes sequence ( Figures 8–9 ). Further, based on the present phylogenetic analysis,
Chondrocladia sagari
sp. nov .
is recovered as a sister species to
C. vaceleti
described by Christobo et al . (2005) from the Angola Basin.

The MGS Sagar cruise 35/36 trawls the seamounts in the CIR which resulted in the discovery of three new species of carnivorous sponges.
Hestetun et al . (2017a)
discovered nine new carnivorous sponge species based on the RRS James Cook expedition along the SWIOR and considered these sponges as seamount endemic species given the comparatively unexplored nature of the area. So far, a total of 18 species of cladorhizid sponge have been reported from the Southwest Indian Ocean Ridge (
Hestetun et al . 2017a
, Table 7). Interestingly, none of the recently described sponge species were from the CIR region. These species perhaps demonstrate regional endemicity to the SWIOR seamount system which needs to be further confirmed by a more meticulous sampling of this vast area. The three new species described in our work from the CIR seamounts could also be regionally endemic, but this hypothesis has to be confirmed with comprehensive sampling and further studies in the CIR seamounts. The new species have similar morphology and spicule characters to
A. ( A. ) pseudoisochela
and
A. ( A. ) jamescooki
from the SWIOR (
Hestetun et al . 2017a
) and
C. clavata
from the Southern Ocean (
Dressler-Allame et al . 2017
). The reconstruction of phylogenetic trees based on mtCOI and 28S genes shows the relative position of new species in the monophyletic group with closely related Cladorhizidae species.

subSection.paragraph:
There has been a phenomenal rise in the discovery of new sponge species, especially of the deep-sea carnivorous sponges, mainly due to an increase in sampling efforts, advancement in deep-sea technology, and use of underwater photography (
Hestetun et al . 2019
). Moreover, the use of molecular techniques and vigilant examination of the older collections by subject experts has further accelerated the rate of redescription of old specimens in different museums from their original description reports (e.g.
Hestetun et al . 2017a
,b,
Ekins et al . 2020
). Hestetun et al . (2017) has described nine new cladorhizid species from the seamount of the SWIOR .
Dressler-Allame et al . (2017)
has reported 29 Cladorhizidae species, including two new species, from the Weddell Sea, Antarctica .
Ekins et al . (2020)
has recently discovered 17 new carnivorous sponge species (family Cladorhizidae ) from the Pacific Ocean and also redescribed four species, which were earlier described by Ridley and Dendy (1886 , 1887 ). Thus, while demonstrating the comprehensiveness of early works, the present study also highlights the need for reaffirming the old collections.

The essential biological factors for larval dispersal of deep-sea benthic fauna are near-bottom deep-water currents such as the Antarctic bottom water current and North Atlantic deep water current through abyssal basins (Mc-Clintock et al . 2005, Downey & Janussen 2015 ). In addition, other environmental factors such as the coastal gyres, stable environmental conditions, lecithotrophic larvae can also control the circum-Antarctic species dispersal (Mc-Clintock et al . 2005, Janussen & Downey 2014 ). In particular,
Ekins et al . (2016)
found astonishing levels of genetic connectivity in deep-sea ‘lithistid’ sponges, with a recovery of the same species across the Pacific Ocean, further confirming the connectivity and distributional pattern of carnivorous sponges (
Hestetun et al . 2019
). Janussen & Downey (2014) and
Göcke et al . (2016)
presented different distributional patterns for many Antarctic sponge species. As the molecular database of these carnivorous species grows, the description of new genera representing these morphological groups will become clearer from their molecular systematics. Although a recent comprehensive molecular study of cladorhizids has been published by
Hestetun et al . (2016)
, no comparable large-scale study has yet been made for the CIR species as to the extent of their connectivity across the Indian Ocean. Although,
Ekins et al . (2016)
found that deep-sea ‘lithistid’ sponge species have unexpected levels of connectivity amongst seamounts south of New Caledonia , more extensive collections across wider areas of the Pacific is required (
Hestetun et al . 2019
). Consequently, the use of remotely operated vehicles in future explorations will decide if the distributions of the two new species in the present study are restricted to the seamounts of CIR, or if they have more widespread distribution across the Indian Ocean. The discovery of three new carnivorous sponge species further supports the earlier findings that the Indian Ocean Mid-oceanic Ridge (MoR) system (Carlsberg Ridge, CIR, and SWIOR ) is having a higher species diversity of cladorhizid sponges in this region.

The present study has shown that there are large areas of the CIR where cladorhizid diversity is poorly known, and therefore, the discovery of three new sponge species is as anticipated. It highlights the uniqueness of the Indian Ocean MoR seamount fauna with a high potential for the discovery of new/unknown species. More specifically, the regional endemic cladorhizid species can be anticipated in the CIR region in previously poorly sampled areas. Moreover, the phylogenetic analysis also suggests the similarity of the CIR species to the SWIOR , Pacific, and Atlantic Oceans. However, there is the potential need for detailed studies to examine possible correlations between geographic separation and similarity between these areas. More exploratory and survey work is being undertaken within, or near this region of the Indian Ocean, primarily by the International Seabed Authority and its collaborators, with the need for rigorous taxonomic work. Further work by the NCPOR in the area would likely recover more undescribed cladorhizids and other benthic species. Through that work, the NCPOR museum (Government of India ) will be capable of increasing its specimen holdings to demonstrate the deep-sea taxonomic groups better as they relate to marine benthic biodiversity in the Indian Ridge systems.

We thank the Ministry of Earth Sciences, Government of India , for all the facilities and Director of NCPOR for encouragement. Our special thanks to Dr. John Kurian, Project Leader, Hydrothermal Program, NCPOR , MoES (Govt. of India ) for his constant support, encouragement and comments on the manuscript. We also acknowledge the help of Chief Scientists of the cruises, crew members of
RV MGS Sagar
, and participants for their willingness to provide onboard assistance in sample collections and processing. We are grateful to Dr. Rahul Mohan for his support of the SEM facility and Dr. K.P. Krishnan for the DNA sequencing facility. We acknowledge Dr. Abhishek Tyagi for help in preparing the maps. Suggestions by Prof. (Dr). John Hooper and two anonymous reviewers helped in describing the new sponge species and improving the overall quality of the manuscript. This is contribution Number J-19/2022-23.
